page_analysis.text_content:
Vaulted entry features
Entry features that are greater than 12' high are called "vaulted entry features". The footprint of such features
count twice toward gross floor area regardless of the design (including whether or not they are open).
How to measure the height of an entry feature in order to determine whether or not
it is considered to be a vaulted entry feature (using Fig 6 - 8 as examples)
Fig 6 Entry feature with shed roof
Note: If the entryway is considered to be a vaulted entryway
the area will be counted as follows:
• In this example, a portion of the entryway is recessed
beyond the house facade and roof. It is included in the
area that counts.
• The area is measured to the outside material of the entry-
way feature.
• The area counts TWICE toward gross floor area.
Intersection of front
facade and top of
roof material
Height
Height
Outline of entry-
way roof
Outline of entryway
floor area that counts
TWICE if entryway is
vaulted
Isometric View
Side Elevation
Porch Floor Plan
||

visual_elements.description: An isometric view of an entry feature with a shed roof, attached to a building facade. It shows a measurement labeled 'Height' from the 'Grade' to the top of the entry feature's roof. Dashed lines indicate the extent of the feature.

A side elevation view of the same entry feature. It illustrates the 'Height' measurement from the ground level to the intersection of the front facade and the top of the roof material. Dashed lines indicate the vertical extent.

A porch floor plan showing the outline of the entryway roof and the outline of the entryway floor area. The floor area is explicitly noted to count 'TWICE if entryway is vaulted'. Dashed lines indicate the roof outline and solid lines indicate the floor area.

technical_specifications.parameter: Minimum height for vaulted entry feature
Gross floor area counting multiplier for vaulted entry features

sections: Entry features that are greater than 12' high are called "vaulted entry features". The footprint of such features count twice toward gross floor area regardless of the design (including whether or not they are open).
How to measure the height of an entry feature in order to determine whether or not it is considered to be a vaulted entry feature (using Fig 6 - 8 as examples)
Note: If the entryway is considered to be a vaulted entryway the area will be counted as follows:

additional_notes: Page number '||' is present at the bottom right corner.

qualifiers.text: Entry features that are greater than 12' high
regardless of the design (including whether or not they are open)
If the entryway is considered to be a vaulted entryway
In this example, a portion of the entryway is recessed beyond the house facade and roof.

conditions.text: The footprint of such features count twice toward gross floor area
It is included in the area that counts.
The area is measured to the outside material of the entry-way feature.
The area counts TWICE toward gross floor area.

logical_relationships.expression: IF (Entry features are greater than 12' high) THEN (they are called "vaulted entry features")
IF (Entry features are greater than 12' high) AND (regardless of the design (including whether or not they are open)) THEN (c1: The footprint of such features count twice toward gross floor area)
IF (the entryway is considered to be a vaulted entryway) THEN (the area will be counted as follows: c2, c3, c4)
IF (the entryway is considered to be a vaulted entryway) AND (a portion of the entryway is recessed beyond the house facade and roof) THEN (c2: It is included in the area that counts.)
IF (the entryway is considered to be a vaulted entryway) THEN (c3: The area is measured to the outside material of the entry-way feature.)
IF (the entryway is considered to be a vaulted entryway) THEN (c4: The area counts TWICE toward gross floor area.)

execution_sequence.action: Determine if an entry feature is 'vaulted'
If vaulted, apply gross floor area counting rule
If considered a vaulted entryway, apply specific area counting rules
